awd_titl_txt: Multilocus analyses of co-diversification and phylogenetic incongruence between highly coevolved figs and fig wasps
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will investigate how interacting species that depend on each other for their own livelihood cause each other to evolve. A broad goal is to understand how such interactions influence the diversification of life on Earth. The researchers will study one of the most ecologically important, highly diverse systems for studying these interactions: figs, their wasp pollinators, and the associated group of parasitic wasps that feed on figs but that don't pollinate them. They plan to test the novel hypothesis that some wasps are able to move onto new hosts, and that these host shifts ultimately lead to decreased genetic differences among wasp species, and thus a breakdown of species' barriers. The project will have important implications for agriculture and food production because the same processes at work in this fig-fig wasp system also determine crop-pest and crop-pollinator relationships. Many college students and young scientists will receive scientific training. A unique educational aspect of the project is the International Field Trip in Biology course, which will allow 12 undergraduates per year to conduct international field research in Panama. 

The research approach is multidisciplinary, involving phylogenetics, population genetics, and volatile chemistry. Genomic sequencing will be used to: 1) obtain well-resolved evolutionary trees of genetic relatedness among Central American fig and fig wasp species, 2) identify subsets of fig species that are, unexpectedly, interbreeding (hybridizing) with each other, and 3) link hybridization of figs to changes in the floral "perfumes" used to attract pollinators, and which are also exploited by parasites to locate host plants. Because this project will include numerous fig and fig wasp species, it will provide the broad frame of reference needed to gain an in depth understanding of the biological and chemical mechanisms underlying the pattern and process of co-diversification across interacting fig and wasp lineages.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

por.por_cntn:
Biologists have long sought to understand processes governing the rate and extent of diversification of Earth’s flora and fauna. With millions of species, plants, their pollinators, and plant-feeding insects are astonishingly diverse and together provide a valuable window into the processes that generate biodiversity and, in turn, crop-pest and crop-pollinator relationships. This project revealed the mechanisms of co-diversification among plant host, pollinator, and parasite species in one of the most ecologically important plant-insect systems known.

Figs and their typically host-specific fig wasp pollinators and parasites have co-evolved for ~90 million years to become both highly diverse (>750 species of figs) and ecologically important “keystone” components of tropical forest ecosystems. The project significantly clarified the processes underlying both the diversification of figs and fig wasps, and their ecological interactions. The research employed a genomic sequencing approach to: 1) obtain well-resolved evolutionary trees of genetic relatedness among Central American fig and fig wasp species, 2) identify subsets of fig species that are, unexpectedly, interbreeding (hybridizing) with each other, and 3) link hybridization of figs to changes in the floral “perfumes” used to attract pollinators, but which are also exploited by parasites to locate host plants. Because this project included numerous fig and fig wasp species, it will provided the broad frame of reference needed to gain an in depth understanding of the biological and chemical mechanisms underlying the pattern and process of co-diversification across interacting fig and wasp linages.

The results of this project have been widely disseminated through multiple means:
•    Twelve articles published in peer-reviewed scientific journals.
•    Four book chapters.
•    Two software products.
•    One symposium organized at an international scientific meeting.
•    Four invited symposia presentations at international meetings.
•    Nine oral presentations at international meetings.
•    Two poster presentations at international meetings.
•    Eight departmental seminar presentations.
•    Three undergraduate research presentations.

The project has also had educational impacts at multiple levels, including the training of four undergraduate research assistants, eight graduate students, and three postdoctoral associates. Additionally, the principal investigators developed a new International Field Trip in Biology course that engaged eleven undergraduates in experiential-based field research and cultural experiences in a biologically diverse third-world setting in Central America.


Last Modified: 10/17/2022
Modified by: John D Nason
